ref: Jour: Physical Review, Part C, Nuclear Physics, Vol.81, p.034608 (2010)
title: Measurement of gamma-emission branching ratios for 154,156,158Gd compound nuclei: Tests of surrogate nuclear reaction approximations for (n,gamma) cross sections

x4freetext: Measurement of gamma-emission branching ratios for
154,156,158Gd compound nuclei: Tests of surrogate
nuclear reaction approximations for (n,gamma) cross
sections

x4codes.hlp: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Berkeley, CA, United States of America

x4freetext: Experiment performed the 88-Inch
Cyclotron at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.
Scattered protons were detected
using the Silicon Telescope Array for Reaction
Studies (STARS) arranged in dE-E1-E2 configuration
Gamma rays were detected using Livermore-
Berkeley Array for Collaborative Experiments
(LiBerACE), which consisted of five clover-type high
purity germanium (HPGe) detectors with bismuth-
germanate-oxide (BGO) Compton-suppression shields.
Coincidence between protons detected in
STARS and gamma ray, detected in LiBerACE was required
The aim of the experiment was to study
possibilities of surrogate method for (n,gamma) cross
section  determination. In analysis a simplified
Weisskopf-Ewing approach which neglect spin/parity
effects in nuclear reactions  was used.
Compiled by S.H.
Measured gamma ray emission probabilities for
154,156 and 158 Gd are presented in fig. 7.  Cross
sections presented in fig. 8 are derived from these
probabilities using surrogate method. Cross section
data are not final, since more sophisticated analysis
is planned. Present results differ by factor of two
from other experimental data.
Measured gamma ray emission probabilities for
154,156 and 158 Gd are presented in fig. 7.  Cross
